title-group.subtitle: A Comprehensive Statistical Package to Analyze Single-System Data

contrib-group.aff: 1Wurzweiler School of Social Work, Yeshiva University, New York, NY, USA

author-notes.corresp: Charles Auerbach, Wurzweiler School of Social Work, Yeshiva University, 2495 Amsterdam Ave, New York, NY 10033, USA. Email: auerbach@yu.edu

abstract.p: The need for statistical analysis in single-subject designs presents a challenge, as analytical methods that are applied to group comparison studies are often not appropriate in single-subject research. SSD for R is a robust set of statistical functions with wide applicability to single-subject research. It is a comprehensive package of statistical tests and produces accompanying graphs for almost every function. These include, among others, tests of autocorrelation, t-tests, effect sizes, median and celeration χ2 analyses, and control charts. All functions and graphs are described in a series of tables. Since SSD for R is open source, it is freely available and can be accessed on the authors’ website, www.ssdanalysis.com. Additional support, including video tutorials and sample data are also available at no charge.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Single-subject research designs, also referred to as single-case evaluations or n = 1 designs, are unique in the realm of research designs as they can serve dual purposes. Often, these evaluations are not designed, at least initially, as research studies, but as a method for social workers to assess their own practices. The notion of social workers evaluating their practices has historically been supported by the National Association of Social Workers (NASW) Code of Ethics (NASW, 2008). More recently, the Council on Social Work Education’s Educational Policy and Accreditation Standards has promoted engaging in research-informed practice and practice-informed research as one of the 10 core social work competencies (Council on Social Work Education (CSWE), 2008). The Council has also promoted using data for the purposes of monitoring client progress and evaluating the effectiveness of interventions (CSWE, 2008; Rubin & Babbie, 2013). Therefore, single-subject research is moving in the direction of being used within the social work profession from being primarily evaluative of individual practice to also include publishable research (e.g., Bernad-Ripoll, 2007; Burke, Kuhn, & Peterson, 2004; Kazi & Wilson, 1996; Schudrich, 2012).

Analysis of single-subject research typically occurs on two levels: Visually and statistically (Mattaini, 2010; Rubin & Babbie, 2011). Visual analysis of data is the most commonly used approach, particularly in practice evaluation (Kazdin, 2011; Orme & Combs-Orme, 2012); however, there are situations in which visual analysis alone may not be sufficient. For example, supplemental statistical analysis may be valuable if the effects are small; the variation is large; the effects of the intervention do not appear immediately as phases change there is no clear trend in the data within phases; or when there may be an issue of autocorrelation, which is nearly impossible to detect through visual inspection alone (Kazdin, 2011; Thyer & Myers, 2011).

As the evidence-based practice movement builds in the social sciences, there is increasing opportunity to include practice-informed research in evaluating the effectiveness of interventions. Therefore, strong research design and statistical analysis are necessary to determine whether an intervention has a causal relationship with outcome measures (Higgins & Green, 2011; Kratochwill et al., 2010; Nugent, 2009).

The need for statistical analysis in single-subject designs, however, presents a challenge, as analytical methods that are applied to group comparison studies are not appropriate in single-subject research. This is due to the fact that single-subject research typically compares measured outcome/outcomes over time under varying conditions, but across the same client unit (e.g., individual, family, or group). Therefore, it is often appropriate to apply different statistical procedures and analysis in single-subject designs than in group comparisons (Kratochwill et al., 2010). These consist of both parametric and nonparametric methods including analysis of autocorrelation, effect size, regression methods, standard deviation band analysis, conservative dual criteria analysis, and others (Bloom, Fischer, & Orme, 2009; Fisher, Kelley, & Lomas, 2003; Kratochwill et al., 2010; Nugent, 2009). Some of these methods are capable of supporting both statistical and visual analysis.

Until now, there has been little in the way of software to help those interested in conducting single-subject research collect, analyze, and interpret their data. While not explicitly shared in published research, many authors appear to use Excel to plot simple line graphs of their data. SINGWIN was the first software package developed by Auerbach, Schnall, and Heft LaPorte in 1999 specifically for the analysis of single-system data in the social sciences (Auerbach, Schnall, & Heft-LaPorte, 2009). SINGWIN was originally developed for educational purposes in order to make the visual and statistical analysis of practice data available to students. It includes t-tests and χ2 tests, among other statistical procedures, and graphs that are written specifically for this type of data (Conboy, Auerbach, Beckerman, Schnall, & LaPorte, 2000). As such, the package has some limitations: Data entry is limited to a single behavior, group data cannot be analyzed, it works only in a Windows environment, and most procedures are limited to A–B designs. Despite these limitations, SINGWIN has been effectively used in published research studies (e.g., Cole, 2002; Schudrich, 2012), and SINGWIN has been promoted as an effective tool for analyzing data in single-subject research (Fisher et al., 2003; Jindani & Newman, 2006; Rock & Cooper, 2000).

Because of the limitations of SINGWIN, a new software application has been developed in R, a statistical programming language, to analyze single-subject data in the social sciences. While not designed to replace SINGWIN, this new application, named SSD for R, has advanced capabilities that may make it more suitable for advanced, publishable research in agency or other settings. These include comprehensive visual and statistical functions for cases that could be considered “single-subject,” whether those cases include individuals, couples, families, groups, or communities (Auerbach & Zeitlin Schudrich, 2012).

sec.title: SSD for R
sec.p: SSD for R does not have the limitations found in SINGWIN. It is a set of functions written in R for the analysis of single-system design data. R is open source (free of charge) and is compatible with Windows, OSX, Linux, and other UNIX variants. R is similar to S, a program developed at Bell Laboratories by John Chambers (The R Project for Statistical Computing, n.d.). It is a programming language for statistical analysis and graphics, which features:

list-item.p: an effective data handling and storage facility,
a suite of operators for calculations on arrays, in particular matrices,
a large, coherent, and integrated collection of intermediate tools for data analysis,
graphical facilities for data analysis and display either on-screen or on hardcopy, and

a well-developed, simple, and effective programming language, which includes conditional, loops, user-defined recursive functions, and input and output facilities (The R Project for Statistical Computing, n.d., paragraph 5).

sec.p: In other words, R provides an environment where statistical techniques can be implemented (The R Project for Statistical Computing, n.d.). R’s capabilities can be extended through the development of functions and packages. Weisberg and Fox (2010, p. xiii) state, “one of the great strengths of R is that it allows users and experts in particular areas of statistics to add new capabilities to the software.” SSD for R is a set of functions that extends the capacity of R to analyze single-system data. Because SSD for R interfaces with Excel, the user can enter multiple dependent (i.e., the behaviors under study) and independent (i.e., baseline/intervention phases) variables. Furthermore, users can analyze any number of phases as well as employ any number of research designs such as A-B, A-B-A, A-B-A-B, B-A-B. There are also procedures for analyzing group data and for the analysis of task-completed data.

As the needs of the single-subject research community grow, it is the authors’ intention to provide comprehensive materials to bolster the usability of the SSD for R functions. This will include additional functionality as the need arises and complete documentation, including help files.

sec.title: Entering Data
sec.p: One of the simplest ways to bring client data into SSD for R for analysis is by entering it into Excel and then importing it into SSD for R. A separate Excel file is needed for each client/group; however, multiple behaviors for each client/group can be tracked in a single Excel file. Figure 1 displays an example.

caption.p: Excel spreadsheet of single-system client data.

sec.p: Notice that the first row (labeled 1), displays the name of the dependent variables across the columns beginning with column A. For each dependent variable, a phase variable needs to be created that indicates in which phase the measurement occurred. For example, Figure 1 displays two dependent variables for a hypothetical client. These variables are called yell and cry. We then created associated phase variables that we called pyell and pcry. In these phase variables, “A”s and “B”s were entered for each observation of the dependent variable to denote in which phase the observation was made. Separate phase variables need to be created for each dependent variable being measured as phase lengths can differ for each dependent variable. Also notice that for “cry,” a third phase, labeled B1 in Excel, was added to denote an enhancement of the original B, or intervention, phase.

Beginning in row 2, data are entered for each time the behavior is measured. Phase changes are marked with “NA” in the behavior and phase variables. Data entry Excel files need to be saved as comma-delimited files. An SSD for R function, Getcsv(), is used for importing data into SSD for R that was created in Excel.

sec.title: Functions Available in SSD for R
sec.p:
As previously mentioned, SSD for R is a set of functions specifically designed for single-subject research. Tables 1
–4 list the functions and describe what each does. Functions are grouped logically according to what they perform:

tr.td: ABplot
Draws a basic line graph for all phases and creates x-axis, y-axis, and main titles for the graph
ABlines or ABlineD
Draws solid or vertical lines between phases on an existing graph
ABtext
Labels graphs with text inside the graph
ABstat
Adds a mean or median line to an existing graph
ABarrow
Allows placement of an arrow anywhere on an existing graph
ABsd1 or ABsd2
Adds horizontal lines at one or two standard deviations to an existing ABplot
Sd1bandgraph or Sd2bandgraph
Draws a line graph for a specific phase showing one or two standard deviations and creates x-axis, y-axis, and main titles for the graph
IQRbandgraph

Draws a line graph for a specific phase showing interquartile ranges and creates x-axis, y-axis, and main titles for the graph. This function also displays the values for the interquartile ranges in the Console
ABiqr
Draws a line graph for all phases of a behavior showing interquantile ranges for a specified phase. This function also displays the values for the specified interquartile ranges in the Console
Cchart

This function draws a control chart for all phases of a behavior showing the values for the upper control limit, mean, and lower control limit for a specified phase. This function also displays the values for the upper control limit, mean, and lower control limit in the Console
Xmrchart

This function draws an XMR chart for any phase showing the values for the upper control limit, mean, and lower control limit. This function also displays the values for the upper control limit, mean, and lower control limit in the Console
Pchart

This function produces a control chart for group data that displays the proportion of a behavior completed over a specified period of time. The upper control limit, mean, and lower control limit are displayed on the graph along with the values for these in the Console

caption.p: Functions Associated With Descriptive and Basic Statistics.

tr.td: ABdescrip

Calculates mean, median, standard deviation, and quantiles for each phase of a behavior. Results are displayed in the Console and are graphically displayed as box plots. Note. This function is also appropriate for analyzing group data
Effectsize
Calculates Cohen’s d and delta for any two phases of a behavior. Parameters for interpretation are included along with the output displayed in the Console
Gindex
Calculates Hedges’ g for any two phases of a behavior. Results are displayed in the Console along with a line graph for the requested phase displaying the mean and regression line for the first phase
Aregres
Calculates a regression line for a phase of a behavior. Results, including residuals, are displayed in the Console. A graph showing the regression line is also displayed

caption.p: Functions Associated With Autocorrelation and Data Transformations.

tr.td: ABrf2

Calculates autocorrelation statistics for any phase of a behavior for the first lag. Values are displayed in the Console along with regression values. A graph showing individual data points and the regression line are also displayed
ABautoacf
Calculates autocorrelation statistics for any phase of a behavior for a specified lag. Values are displayed in the Console. A series TSX graph displays autocorrelation values between lags
Diffchart

Displays a difference chart for any phase of a behavior and gives the option in the Console to save transformed data. Transformed data are then displayed in the Console. Important note. If you are using a PC, you may need to minimize RStudio in order to see the Save As window
ABma

Displays a moving average chart for any phase of a behavior and gives the option in the Console to save transformed data. Transformed data are then displayed in the Console. Important note. If you are using a PC, you may need to minimize RStudio in order to see the Save As window
Append()
Allows the merging of two data files into a third

caption.p: Functions Associated With Tests of Type I Error.

tr.td: ABanova

This function performs an analysis of variance for all phases of a behavior in addition to a Tukey post-hoc test. A graph showing the mean differences for each combination of phases is displayed. Note. This function is also appropriate for analyzing group data
ABbinomial
This function calculates the proportion of successes, as defined by the user, for each of two phases
CDC

This function calculates the number of data points required above and below the mean and regression lines to obtain statistical significance between phases and provides a total count for these. A simple line graph showing both phases and the mean and the regression line for the first phase is displayed
celabove or celbelow

This function calculates the number and percentage of data points above or below the regression line in the first phase across phases. A simple line graph showing both the phases and the regression line for the first phase is displayed. Note. This function is also appropriate for analyzing group data
medabove or medbelow

This function calculates the number and percentage of data points above or below the median line in the first phase across phases. A simple line graph showing both the phases and the median line for the first phase is displayed. Note. This function is also appropriate for analyzing group data
ABttest

This function performs a Student’s t-test across any two phases of a behavior. A bar chart displaying the means of each phase is displayed. Note. This function is also appropriate for analyzing group data

sec.title: Individual Client Data Analysis Example
sec.p: Figure 2 displays an example of data from an A-B-B1 design, which was produced using the ABplot function to display a hypothetical client’s crying behavior. With SSD for R, a user can clarify this graph by placing lines to denote phase changes; add text to label the phases; and place mean, median, and standard deviation lines. Figure 2 illustrates this capability with a mean line added to each phase. As the figure clearly shows, the mean behavior decreases between phases. All graphs produced in SSD for R can be saved for import into other programs (e.g., word processing) or for later use.

caption.p: Plot of A-B-B1 design produced by the AB plot function.

sec.p:
In accordance with accepted statistical analysis of single-system data, the phases should be tested for autocorrelation using the ABrf2 function before testing for statistical differences (Bloom et al., 2009). If the data were autocorrelated, they could be transformed using differencing (using the diffchart function) or the moving average (using the ABma function) and combined into a transformed data set for analysis. In addition, graphs of both the original and transformed data are produced automatically with each of these functions. As an example, Figure 3 shows output for the ABrf2 function for our hypothetical client’s yelling behavior. From this output, we see that the autocorrelation is low and not significant in either phase (rf
2 = −0.57 for the baseline and rf
2 = −0.23 for the intervention, p > .05 for both phases).

caption.p: Test of autocorrelation for client’s yelling behavior.

sec.p: Before deciding how to statistically analyze our client’s yelling behavior between phases, it is helpful to determine whether there is a trend in one or more of the phases. This can be accomplished using the ABregres function in SSD for R. The visual output for this is shown in Figure 4.

caption.p: Visual output to analyze trend across phases for client’s yelling behavior.

sec.p: We can see from this output that there is no trend in either the baseline or the intervention, and statistical output from this function indicates that the slope for the baseline is −0.02 (p > .05) and is −.04 for the intervention (p > .05).

Since there is no issue of autocorrelation and there is no trend in either phase, we can compare yelling behavior across phases by using a t-test, which is accomplished in SSD for R with the function ABttest. Figure 5 shows output from this function.

sec.title: Group Data Analysis Example
sec.p: A major addition in SSD for R is the abilty to analyze group data. Figures 6 and 7 display an analysis of group cohesion over 8 weeks for eight different group members. The data come from an example found in Evaluating practice: Guidelines for the accountable professional (Bloom et al., 2009). The boxplot in Figure 6 is generated automatically when the ABdescrip function is used. It displays the degree of variation in cohesion between group members with the last week showing the lowest degree of difference between group members. Additionally, descriptive statistics for each week is provided. As displayed in Figure7, group data can also be analyzed between phases. In this case, an above median χ2 analysis was completed to discern whether group cohesion improved between phases. Although not significant (p = .055), 71% (28 of 39) of scores above the baseline median level of cohesion occurred during the intervention. When appropriate, regression, t-tests, median line analysis, and celeration line analysis can also be conducted on group data.

caption.p: Descriptive statistics and boxplots of group data.
Above median χ2 test of group cohesion data with median graph.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: SSD for R is a robust set of statistical functions with wide applicability to single-subject research. Since it is open source, it is freely available and can be accessed on the authors’ website, www.ssdanalysis.com.

This website contains links to download R and RStudio, a graphical user interface that enables simultaneous viewing of statistical and graphical output. The website also contains numerous videos that provide tutorial support for the use of SSD for R functions, a method for registering to keep up-to-date with improvements to the website and functions, additional supporting documentation, and comprehensive examples for each function.

It is the authors’ hope that SSD for R will enable social work practitioners and researchers to conduct more advanced and rigorous forms of single-subject research. As the field of practice-based social work research grows, it is the authors’ intention to dynamically improve and adapt SSD for R to meet the needs of the research community.

fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The authors received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
